+Giggle Gasm Actually. The wording is "The Flu vaccine does not normally 
cause side effects but can cause stiffness and a mild fever for a few days 
after taking it" Which sounds a lot like "flu like symptoms" But it is

mostly only happens in people with weak immune systems.

There have also been recorded cases of people developing the flu 
immediately after taking the vaccine but there is inconclusive evidence 
whether it was due to the vaccine or whether they were infected before they 
took the vaccine.

top_comment.text:
+DNews
I had H1N1
, got it 2009.10.30 on halloween party from foreigners (was working in 
night club).
Had 26,8C before going to sleep at 11.03 (i was feeling tired so i took my 
temp all was ok), 2 hours later woke up with 40.3C fever.
I called a family member to bring me 3 cartons(2L each) of 50+% pure orange 
juice, and 4 day later i was feeling much better (i slept all those 4 
days), so the flu was no big deal, like any other cold basically.
I actually got really bad complication/aggravation from the Flu namely 
trigeminal neuralgia (had an operation on it too, hospitalized for 3 weeks).
As described in the wikipedia "It has been described as among the most 
painful conditions known to humankind." and the description was for the 
standard "Trigeminal neuralgia" and i have the type 2 (worse) variant 
namely "Atypical trigeminal neuralgia", and this is for life. There is no 
way to regrow new nerves.
This year was the second worse i have had it (first was the first time), 
now it lasted from the 2nd week in january to the first 2 days of march. 
(It makes you rip out your head it's that bad).﻿

top_comment.author: Sho Bud

comments.text:
+DraekosFilms The official recommendation in Denmark is that healthy people 
don't need it unless they are at risk of infecting sick people, these are 
doctors, nurses and caregivers of the elderly and sick.

The people that should get vaccinated, according to the infectious medicine 
deparment, are people with respiratory problems and people with compromised 
immune systems, like HIV/AIDS, diabetes, elderly and people with a BMI over 
40.

This is, according to them, is due to a cost-benefit analysis that shows 
healthy people are more expensive to vaccinate than the benefits they gain 
from being vaccinated.

+Falney The flu vaccine takes around two weeks to protect you from the flu. 
Also, most modern flu vaccinations just use surface proteins of the viruses 
they are supposed to protect against. They don't use actual viruses, so it 
would be impossible to get the flu from them, as there is no virus RNA in 
the vaccine. Old vaccines used live viruses that were inactivated - these 
could cause actual flu, if they weren't prepared properly.
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text:
+Hop lite There are actually recorded cases of people developing the Flu 
shortly after taking the vaccine how ever, it is all empirical data, i.e. a 
correlation being observed. How ever as we know. correlation =/= causation. 

There is no evidence to prove nor disprove whether the vaccine causes Flu 
in some patients, only a speculation at this point. It has how ever been 
documented that it can cause flu like symptoms in some patients (in rare 
cases). Painful joints, stiff muscles, headache, slight fever etc.
comments.author: Falney

comments.text:
+Hop lite
I appreciate the humor, sir. Thanks!
comments.author: New American Fishkeeper

comments.text:
+DraekosFilms Of course the doctors would say yes.

The way I see it, in a sense yes, to protect others who may have been 
immunized but not as successfully due to weaker immune systems etc. It also 
might lighten the symptoms if you do get the bad flu in the end. However if 
one is healthy and rarely gets the flu, while having a lifestyle that does 
not include danger groups, I see no benefit in the vaccine for them. 

It always helps to remember that even those who get vaccinated have a 40% 
chance get infected and carry the virus too. 

Also a lot of the False impressions of people that "got the flu because of 
the vaccine" is probably people getting a Cold, which has nothing to do 
with the Flu virus.
comments.author: Josh Mango

comments.text:
Alright. Thanks.

Considering the efficacy of the vaccine though wouldn't it be still worth 
it to take it anyway?
comments.author: methylDragon

comments.text:
This one has a shit load of links
http://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/qa/publications.htm

But this one is a nice summary. 
http://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/qa/vaccineeffect.htm

In it you will find that effectiveness is in the 60% area, that it is more 
crucial for people of age and danger groups. You will also find that each 
year they project the effectiveness and also measure it afterwards, which 
unavoidably shows fluctuation in the immunization effect success rate 
depending on the vaccine being close enough to the actual virus going on 
rise. 

Also elder people and those with respiratory are the ones who actually die 
in significant numbers of flue, while other groups tend to heal that's why 
they include this in their factsheet below. 
http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs211/en/

As I understand the data, unless you come into daily contact with children 
and elderly people, and you are generally healthy, you really have no great 
personal benefit or benefit to others by taking the seasonal vaccination. 

I only have had the typical vaccines. I never used a seasonal flue vaccine, 
and I have not got the flu not even once in 15 years. 

I do not see how a 60% success vaccine could improve my condition.
comments.author: Josh Mango

comments.text:

captions.text:
This episode of DNews is brought to you by
HARRY’S.

So, it's cold and flu season. That sucks.
But whenever I feel crappy, I can't tell if

I've got the cold, or the flu -- does it matter?
What's the difference?!

When I get a cough, or a headache or whatever
for a few days, I always assume it will go

away, or that I just have a cold… but sometimes…
it's the FLU! Even though the medicine says

its for both the cold and the flu, they're
entirely different viruses. The common cold

is caused by over 200 different viruses! Coronaviruses,
rhinoviruses, metapneumoviruses, enteroviruses

and parainfluenza viruses all make the short
list; but they really are all different. This

is why we can't "cure" the common cold. The
flu, on the other hand, is caused by influenza

viruses. These respiratory viruses invade
the body and set up shop and cause very similar

symptoms, because the human body only has
so many ways to fight.

When your body is invaded by a virus, chances
are you'll get the same symptoms every time,

dry or sore throat, coughing and sneezing,
mild fever, congestion and maybe a headache.

Pretty standard stuff. If it's REALLY bad,
you'll get aches and pains and exhaustion

too. This happens because your body is spending
resources fighting off the viral infection.

In general, flu is worse than the common cold,
the fever is higher, the aches and level of

exhaustion are more pronounced, and the cough
can be more intense. While there's almost

no way to tell the difference between the
two infections… colds tend to produce a

fever less than 101 (38C), affects the throat
and cause a runny nose. The flu, affects the

lungs and the joints -- so you're likely to
feel more achy than leaky.

Telling the difference is one thing, but once
you're infected you only have a couple days

to get treatment. After the first 48 hours,
the infection has usually stopped multiplying

and is wreaking havoc on the body instead.
Regardless, once symptoms start for viral

infections, there's no simple cure. Antibiotics
WILL NOT HELP, because they fight BACTERIA

not VIRUSES. Taking an antibacterial drug
during a viral infection is pointless.

In fact, a lot of the remedies for colds and
the flu aren't really based on… well science.

Many people take vitamin C like it's going
out of style, but a study from the University

of Alberta looked at results and found there's
really no evidence that it helps. Results

suggest it MIGHT help with marathon runners
who have compromised immune systems due to

exhaustion, but even then it's a minor help.
I like to take zinc when I'm starting to feel

ill, and science DOES support that. Zinc is
used by human immune cells as a catalyst,

so when you boost the amount of zinc your
immune cells can protect the body a bit better,
but too much can damage it -- so don't overmedicate.

In the end, a cold will persist for 10 days,
while some flu symptoms will persist for three

weeks; long after the influenza virus has
been eradicated. If you REALLY want to avoid

getting sick, get a flu vaccination. Only
30 percent of surveyed adults get vaccinated

year over year. Flu vaccines are made every
year by specialists who use massive datasets

to predict which influenza viruses will dominate
this season -- see, there's more than one

mutation, and they vie for power and bodies
to infect. The 2014 flu vaccine will protect

against Influenza A H1N1 and H3N2, as well
as a couple influenza B viruses. You might

recognize H1N1, we're still seeing that left
over from 2009's unexpected flu epidemic!
Crazy right?

So yes, there IS a difference between colds
and flu, but if you catch one of the over

200 viruses that cause these crappy feelings
the best way to handle it is to drink fluids

and help keep yourself hydrated and rest.
If you minimize nutritional strain on your

immune system by enjoying warm chicken soup
and let your immune system do it's work, you'll

be fine. Empathy can also help, studies have
shown people who have families or even an

empathetic doctor recover faster than those
who don't so help out a friend if they're

sick, but don't catch it yourself. If you
insist on medication, decongestants and antihistamines

will treat the symptoms of both cold and flu,
but again -- don't take antibacterial meds

unless you know it's a bacterial infection
-- that's something a doctor can tell you.

And speaking of stuff you keep in the medicine
cabinet, if you’re looking for a good razor

to shave with try Harry's! Harry's was started
by a couple guys who liked shaving so much

that bought a razor factory to make their
own. They're cheap, they show up at your door,

and they're sharp both in look and… well,
sharpness. Just go to Harrys.com and use the

promo code DNews to save $5 off your first
order AND you’ll be supporting the show.

title: Cold vs. Flu: What's The Difference?
